justification: Participants rated each food on the question: “In this situation, how good it would be to make this food…?”, using a 1 (worst) to 7 (best) scale, thereby operationalising context-specific value with a 7-point Likert scale.

For general cached value we asked, “In general, how much do you like eating this food…?”, recorded on the same 1-to-7 scale, so overall liking on a 7-point Likert item served as the measure of cached value.
Study 3 added the item, “How often do you eat each of these foods…?”, answered on a 1 (least common) to 7 (most common) scale, which was used to quantify historical choice frequency.

Immediately after choosing, participants were “asked them to retrospectively report every candidate they had considered before settling on their final answer,” providing a behavioural listing that measured the contents of the consideration set.
